optimizeAlarms.pageDescription: Use artificial intelligence to adjust your greenhouse alarm settings for optimized cocoa fermentation. Provide your specific conditions, and our AI will suggest personalized temperature limits.
optimizeAlarmsForm.title: AI Alarm Optimization
optimizeAlarmsForm.description: Provide details about your cocoa cultivation to receive AI-based recommendations for optimal temperature alarm limits. All data is processed securely.
optimizeAlarmsForm.microclimateInfoPlace: Describe humidity levels, sun exposure, ventilation systems, greenhouse size, etc.
optimizeAlarmsForm.historicalDataDescrip: Provide a JSON array of objects, each with "timestamp" (Unix milliseconds) and "temperature" (Celsius) fields.
optimizeAlarmsForm.historicalDataError: Historical data is required and must be valid JSON.
optimizeAlarmsForm.unknownError: An unknown error occurred during optimization.
optimizationResultCard.title: Optimized Alarm Settings
optimizationResultCard.description: Based on the provided data, here are the AI-recommended temperature alarm limits.

hardwareAssembly.title: Hardware Assembly Guide
hardwareAssembly.description: Follow this step-by-step guide to assemble your first temperature sensor prototype with ESP32 and DS18B20.
hardwareAssembly.component6: USB cable to connect the ESP32 to the computer
hardwareAssembly.wiringDiagramDescriptio: The image below illustrates how the components should be connected. Follow the wire colors for ease.
hardwareAssembly.wiringDiagramAlt: Wiring diagram of ESP32 with DS18B20 sensor
hardwareAssembly.step1Title: Position the ESP32 on the Breadboard
hardwareAssembly.step1Description: Fit the ESP32 board in the center of the breadboard, straddling the central divider. This allows you to access the pins on both sides.
hardwareAssembly.step2Description: Use jumpers to connect the '3V3' (or 3.3V) pin of the ESP32 to the positive power rail (+) of the breadboard (usually marked in red). Connect the 'GND' pin of the ESP32 to the negative ground rail (-) of the breadboard (marked in blue).
hardwareAssembly.step3Description: Plug the DS18B20 sensor into the breadboard. Connect the VCC (power) pin of the sensor to the positive rail (+). Connect the GND pin of the sensor to the negative rail (-). Connect the DATA pin of the sensor to a GPIO pin on the ESP32, such as pin 'GPIO 4' (or D4).
hardwareAssembly.step4Description: Connect the 4.7kΩ resistor between the DATA pin of the sensor (the same one connected to GPIO 4) and the positive power rail (+). This resistor is crucial for stable communication with the sensor.
hardwareAssembly.step5Description: Review all connections to ensure they are correct and firm. Once confirmed, connect the USB cable from your computer to the ESP32 board. An LED on the board should light up, indicating it is powered on.
hardwareAssembly.nextStepsDescription: With the hardware assembled, the next step is to program the ESP32. You can use the free **Arduino IDE** software to write and upload code to your ESP32 (no physical Arduino board is needed). PlatformIO is another great alternative.
login.pendingApproval: Your account is pending administrator approval.
forgotPassword.pageDescription: Don't worry! Enter your email below and we'll send you a reset link.
forgotPassword.successMessage: If an account with this email exists, a password reset link has been sent.
traceability.pageDescription: Record all important information for each cocoa lot to ensure quality and traceability.

traceability.lotDescriptionPlaceholder: E.g., Cocoa from the June harvest
traceability.qrCodeTitle: Lot Registered and QR Code Generated
traceability.qrCodeDescription: The QR Code below contains all the lot information. Print it to attach to the physical lot.
traceability.saveSuccessDescription: The traceability record was saved and the QR code has been generated.
traceability.qrCodeErrorDescription: Could not generate the QR code for this lot.
traceability.savedLotsDescription: View and manage all the cocoa lots you have registered.
traceability.noLotsFound: No lots registered yet. Start by registering a new lot.
